Award.AwardTitle: DISSERTATION RESEARCH: Assessing Homology of Hoofed Mammal Cranial Appendages with 3D Morphometrics and Next-Generation Transcriptomics
Award.AbstractNarration:
The horns, antlers, and other bony structures (cranial appendages) growing from the skulls of even-toed, hoofed mammals like deer, antelopes, and giraffes (the group of hoofed mammals called Pecora) are an evolutionary mystery. Cranial appendages are often used to determine how species are related to the different families of Pecora, because each family is distinguished by the presence of a specific type of appendage. When fossil species lack cranial appendages, it is difficult to assign them reliably to any particular family. These appendage-less fossil species could provide necessary information about the ancestral origins of cranial appendages in each family, but the inability to confidently place them in the context of pecoran evolutionary relationships precludes their use in studies of cranial appendage evolution. Prior studies have shown that variation in the way structures change as an animal grows can result in the origination of totally new structures. A better understanding of cranial appendage development will therefore provide much-needed context for hoofed mammal cranial appendage evolution and help resolve the question of their origins. It will also contribute to research on how skin and connective tissues contribute to bone growth and have implications for understanding pathways and patterns of skull development, with methods and results that are broadly applicable to skull and bone growth research in all vertebrates, including humans. This research will form the basis of a curriculum on genomic analyses and genetics for middle school students in the American Museum of Natural History's Lang Science Program, piloted with diverse groups of New York schoolchildren and available to teachers and schools across the country.

This project will test two competing hypotheses: 1) the broad range of distinctive cranial appendages observed in fossil and extant pecoran artiodactyls do not share a common evolutionary origin, 2) portions of cranial appendages, such as the permanent bone pedicles of antlers and the bone cores of horns, may be homologous across some or all of the appendage types in this clade. Samples will be collected from the cranial appendage forming tissues of at least three individuals each from the four extant cranial-appendage-bearing families of Pecora (Bovidae, Cervidae, Giraffidae, and Antilocapridae) and an appendage-less outgroup taxon from Tragulidae, at 3 developmental stages: birth, one month, and two months old. RNA will be isolated from these tissues and sequenced using next-generation sequencing technologies. Gene expression profiles sequenced from tissues at a second location on the body of each individual will provide a somatic control to estimate gene expression specifically related to cranial appendage growth (the cranial appendage transcriptome). These transcriptomes will be optimized onto a phylogeny to test for homology of the genes responsible for cranial appendage growth across and within age groups.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Intellectual Merit

Understanding the evolution of horns, antlers, and other bony outgrowths (cranial appendages) of even-toed, hoofed mammals (or artiodactyls, e.g., deer, sheep, cattle, giraffes) has long captured the interest of scientists. Why has this group of animals evolved so many types of ornaments and weapons, and do those wildly different structures share a common evolutionary origin? Despite positional and compositional similarities (i.e., all located on the frontal or parietal bones of the skull, and composed in part by permanent bone), whether they evolved a single time or multiple times has been difficult to discern. By investigating how shape and gene expression change across development, I tested two hypotheses: 1) cranial appendages do not share a common origin (i.e., they evolved separately multiple times), and 2) portions of cranial appendages, such as the permanent bone core of horns and the permanent bone base of antlers, share a common evolutionary origin and observed differences between the structures evolved later. Using a morphological approach with computer-based three-dimensional (3D geometric morphometric) shape analyses and complementing those analyses with DDIG-supported gene expression analyses, I was able to show that early stages of cranial appendage development share similar directions of shape growth in both horns and antlers. The DDIG-supported gene expression analyses were important in showing the patterns of gene expression in growing horns that distinguish them from other cattle body tissues are more similar to the gene expression of cattle skin and antler tissues than to other cattle tissues. Testing gene expression of polled (hornless) sheep showed that the genetic mechanisms that turn off horn growth in bovids are similar across multiple species, and also share some similarities to the gene expression in the permanent bone base of antlers during the seasons in which antlers are not growing. This similarity could be evidence for homology and a single common origin of these structures: if the mechanism that turns off cranial appendage growth is the same, it could be counteracting the same underlying genetic mechanism that exists to turn it on in these species. Overall, these analyses provide evidence, through both similar pathways of shape development and similar gene expression, for the shared evolutionary origin of horns and antlers, contradicting the hypothesis that they do not share a common origin, and instead supporting the hypothesis that at least some portion of cranial appendages evolved a single time in the ancestry of this group of mammals.

 

Broader Impacts 

My dissertation research was the basis for a new curriculum on the evolution of morphology for an American Museum of Natural History (AMNH) Lang Science Program for sixth and seventh grade students, many from groups underrepresented in science and from underserved or underperforming urban schools, as well as multiple outreach presentations to a variety of audiences. I participated in two Facebook Live videos on the AMNH Facebook page, which were viewed by tens of thousands of people around the U.S. and across the world and allowed me to answer questions on the growth and differences between cranial appendage types for the general public, reaching far beyond only the people who are able to visit the museum in person. These broadcast videos, now archived on the museum’s Facebook page (with approximately one million followers), are a valuable way to extend the unique educational opportunities provided in a museum setting to a much larger audience. In addition to the Facebook presentations, I also gave in-person presentations of my dissertation research to numerous school and public groups, including the Meet the Scientist and Tree of Life programs at AMNH, that reach students from local underserved communities, and at St. Hilda’s and St. Hugh’s school in New York City, as well as remote presentations for the San Francisco Brightworks School. These presentations were an essential way of spreading the knowledge I gained through the PhD process to the public.
